I not Riley shortly afterwards in the 'Ship Aground' public-house in Lee Bridge Road, and asked him if he knew anyone who had a trust Riley said his landlord would lend him one for a bit of silver. I saw Lovell standing outside with the cob, harness, and cart. He took it away. Next morning (Tuesday, August 6), he came round about 9 a.m. and asked if I knew anyone who would buy a cob. I said, 'Yes,' and took the cob down to Mr. Luck at Dorking, and sold it to him. Lovell left me, and I have not seen him since. On the way to Dorking, I met Riley and Gardner in the Old Ford Road, and took them for a drive. I made inquiries about the trap, and found it belonged to a man named Head, Riley's landlord."

To Mr. Thomas. When I first saw Head he said he did not lend it, but when it was a question of coming to police court to charge Riley with stealing the cart he said he remembered that he had lent it to him.

Superintendent
GEORGE BOON , Surrey Constabulary. At 4.45 p.m. on August 6 I saw prisoner Friend in Pixham Lane, Dorking. He was driving a bay gelding in an old two-wheel cart. I stopped him and asked him if his name was Jack smith. He replied, "No, John Friend." I told him I was going to arrest him on another charge and conveyed him to Dorking Police Station. Ascertaining that two men had been in his company, I went out and found them, prisoner Riley being one and the other a man named Gardner. They were also taken to Dorking Police Station, where all three were charged with being concerned in the robbery. Friend replied, "I got the horse from a man named Jack Lovell, of Bethnal Green, and the other two men only came with me for a rids." Riley said, "That is right." The other man made no reply. The horse was afterwards identified by Mrs. Munday, and the harness at North London Police
Court. Inside the cart was the square oil lamp produced, a collar, and the halter, which has been identified by Mrs. Munday. Gardner was discharged at the North London Police Court.
(Defence.)

JOHN FRIEND (prisoner, on oath). On Bank Holiday night (August 5) I was in Lea Bridge Road, accompanied by my brother and my sister-in-law, when I met a man named Lovell leading a harnessed horse with a rug over it. He said, "My trap has broken down up the road and I have left it. Do you know where I can borrow one?" I said, "No, I do not." Outside the "Shop Aground" I met Riley with Gardner. I said to Riley, "Do you know anybody that can lend a chap a trap." Riley said, "My landlord has got one. He will lend it to you for a bit of silver." Meanwhile we went to Nesbit Street, where Head lives, and dragged the trap round to the "Stag" public-house in Brooksby's Walk, where Lovell said he would meet me with the horse and harness. Lovell put the horse in the trap and away he went, saying to me, "Do you know anybody that will buy the old cob. I am a bit short of money and want to go to the market to-morrow." On the following morning I met him in Old Ford Road, and he asked me, "Did I know anybody who buy his horse?" I told him "Yes." He can said, "Here it is; do what you like with it. I want £10 down for it or you can have an exchange for another one, as I want some money." I got up into the trap, and going along the Old Ford Road I met Gardner and Riley. I said, "Halloa, would you like to go for a ride?" They said they did not mind and got up and accompanied me to Droking. When I got to Pixham Lane I left Riley and Gardner at the top of the lane while I went down to where I was going to sell the horse. I am perfectly innocent of having stolen the horse. I had seen Lovell on the Thursday before at Spitalfields Market with some bananas on his cart with a horse exactly like the one he gave me to sell, and I thought it was the same horse when I saw it one the Monday night.

Cross-examined. After I had sold the horse I intended to put the cart on the rail and send it up to London Bridge. I think I had 10 1/2 d. in my pocket. That would not have paid for sending back the cart, but I should have had money after I had sold the horse. It did not strike me to ask any questions about the harness or the horse because I had seen Lovell with it on the previous Thursday. He keeps a fruit stall somewhere in the Bethnal Green Road. When I was arrested at Dorking they asked me who this Lovell was, and I told the detective as far as lay in my power. I did not know Lovell very well, only through having seen him up and down. Lovell promised me a bit of gold if I sold the horse. I was to meet Lovell again after I had sold the cob at the corner of Brick Lane, Bethnal Green Road the same night. I have never seen Lovell since as, of course, I have been in custody, whereas if I had been out on bail I might have had a chance to look about for him.
To the Court. I did not cut the horse's tail; it is very saldom I carry a knife. I have known Riley five or six months.

HENRY RILEY (prisoner, on oath). I am a costermonger and live at 31, Nesbit Street, Homerton. On August 5 I was at the "Skip Aground," Lea Bridge Road, at about ten o'clock with a lad named Gardner. Friend came up and asked me if I knew where he could borrow a cart. I said, "Yes, I think so. My landlord has got use. and I have no doubt he will let you have that if you give him a bit of silver for the hiring of it." I went with Friend to Head's leaving the horse behind at "The Stag" in charge of another man Head was under the influence of drink, but I asked him if he would lend "Little Jack"—meaning Friend—his cart, and he said "You." Head said he would let him have the cart, and he took it away. I then parted company with Friend. Next morning I was again in company with Gardner in the Old Ford Road. We met Friend with a horse and cart. He pulled up and asked where we were bound for Being holiday time, we said we had nothing to do. Friend then said, "Would you like to go for a ride?" We thereupon got into she came and Friend drove us to Dorking. In Pixham Lane he asked us to get down while he was doing his business. We waited close upon an hour, and then Superintendent Boon arrested us and took us to the station, and charged us with stealing the pony. I did not steeling the pony, and know nothing about it or about the harness. Is in true that Mrs. Munday sold me some harness, and I dispossed of a to a friend named Smith, a greengrocer. I do not recognise the collar as the one which Mrs. Munday sold me. I think it was the second week in January last that I bought the harness.

Cross-examined. We drove from Old Ford Road to Epsom, and stayed there an hour, and I suppose it would be three o'clock when we reached Dorking. We pulled up several times, and, of course had a drink at each place. I had 4s. or 5s. when we started. Friend was supposed to meet a man at Epsom, but did not do so. We talked about various things over our beer, but it never struck me to the Friend what he was going to Dorking for; it did not concern no at all. I merely went for the ride, it being holiday time. I never considered how I was to get back, but I think Friend said he was going to exchange the horse. I am a fairish judge of a horse. The was a very aged old cob and showed a lot of wear. There was on old collar in the cart. It did not strike me to ask what it was doing there. I heard Mrs. Munday say she sold me that very celler, but that is a lie. I do not know where it came from or where the other harness came from. I heard Mrs. Munday say that I had taken a fancy to her cob on more than one occasion. That is false. I had never seen her cob in my life until I went for this ride with Friend and never wanted to buy it. I know Clapton pretty well. I suppose the "Ship Aground" is about a quarter of an hour's walk trass Reader's Field, where Mrs. Munday's horse was stolen from. Harvey's stable is close by.

HERBERT GARDNER . I am 18 and live at 58, Cross Street, Hackney. On August 5 I was at the "Ship Aground" in company with Riley. From came up with another man leading a harnessed horse, and asked if he could borrow a trap. (Witness gave further corroborative evidence.)

JAMES SMITH , greengrocer, Brunswick Street, Hackney. I know Biley, and bought some harness of him about nine months ago. I also bought the harness produced from Mrs. Munday. I think that was about nine months ago.
EDWARD DAWS , 173 Brick Lane, printer's cutter, also gave evidence as to the harness belonging to Harvey.

WILLIAM HEAD , 31, Nesbit Street, Homerton, carman, gave evi
dence as to lending the cart to Friend at Riley's request.

Verdict, both
Guilty, and both confessed to previous convictions.

Detective-inspector SIMMONDS, D Division, stated that in 1901 Riley was sentenced to three years' penal servitude at the North London. Sessions for horse stealing. On January 22, 1894, at the same sessions he was sentenced to five years' penal servitude also for horse stealing, and there was a prior conviction for horse stealing on Feb
ruary 4, 1889. Altogether he had had 13 years' penal servitude for horse stealing, and was at the present time reporting to the police on his licence. For years he had been extensively engaged in stealing horses from Hackney Marshes and the surrounding districts, which he know intimately. With regard to Friend, the police had great difficulty in detecting a man of his class, as he was engaged in horse dealing. Witness had pulled him up taking horses along which had turned out to be correct horses, and Friend had then made a com
plaint to the Commissioner that he had been prevented from getting an honest living.

Detective-sergeant HAWKINS said that Friend had against him only one conviction of three months for horse stealing, with the excep
tion of the conviction yesterday for stealing a mare and a gelding, but he was the associate of notorious horse thieves, one of whom was sentenced to four years' penal servitude and another to 18 months last Sessions. There was a great deal of this horse stealing going on, people turning their horses out to grass in the early part of the year, and the sufferers were generally poor people who could ill afford to lose their animals.

Judge Lumley Smith said he was satisfied that Riley was a con
firmed horse stealer or dealer in stolen horses, and he could not pass a less sentence than
Five years' penal servitude. Friend,
Three years' penal servitude for each offence, to run concurrently.
BEFORE JUDGE RENTOUL.
(Wednesday, September 18.)

p.rs:
, stealing two china vases, the property of
Edward Ager.

div1.p: Mr. W. S. M. Knight prosecuted.

EDWARD AGER , builder, High Street, Plaistow. On Saturday, August 31, about 11 p.m., I went to see a neighbour a few doors away, leaving my door ajar. After a short time I returned and met charles Smith and a policeman; on going into my house I found that two vases, which were there when I left, had disappeared; their value was 5s. 6d. I have known prisoner several years and have employed him. At the police court he declared that he took those vases for wages due to him; I saw there were no wages due at all; I do not owe him a penny. I never authorised him to take the vases.

To Prisoner. You saw me during the week. I paid Ellis, the fishmonger, 3s. out of wages due to you; this was by your instruc
tions.

CHARLES SMITH , labourer, 6, Albert Road, Plaistow. On August 31, about 11.20 p.m., I was sitting in my front garden when prisoner came and asked me if I wanted to buy a pair of vases; I said., "No"; he said, "come on, you can have them for a shilling." I asked him where he had pinched them; he said he got them from the fair at Wantead. He showed them to me; they ratiled, and I told him he would break them; so he turned them upside down. Three or four cards fell out; one had on the name and address of Mr. Ager, so I took the card to him. I did not take the vases; prisoner took them away.

Detective-sergeant
FREDERICK STEVENS , Plaistow. On Septem
ber 1 I went to prisoner in a public-house and told him that I was a police officer and should arrest him for stealing a pair of went from Ager's house the previous night. He said, "All right." I said, "I shall send you to the station while I go to your house." He said, "It's no use going round there, they're smashed; I would have smashed his b——head if I had met him." At the station he made no reply to the charge. I have not been able to find the vases.
PRISONER. What I said was that if I had met him I should have hit him on the head to the vases.
Prisoner's statement before the magistrate: "I took them for wages."

PRISONER (not on oath). I met Ager several times during the week and asked him for my wages; he said, "All right, old boy." On the Saturday I went to his house 20 times, and he was always out. I met Ellis, the fishmonger, who told me, "I have seen Ager, end he has given me 2s. out of your money, and he is going to give me the other 1s. by and bye"; I said, "What, give you 3s. out of 3s. 4d.; how am I going on about dinner to-morrow if I've only get 4d. to take?" I subpoeaned Ellis for to-day, but he refused to take the subpoens.

Verdict,
Guilty. Prisoner confessed to a previous conviction, and his record was a very bad one. Sentence,
12 months' hard labour.
BEFORE THE COMMON SERJEANT.
(Thursday, September 19.)

p.rs:
; feloniously receiving one Ralli car, one gelding, one set of harness, and other articles, the goods of
William McGinty, well knowing the same to have been stolen.

div1.p: Mr. Sydney E. Williams prosecuted; Mr. Purcell defended.

WILLIAM MCGINTY , 718, Barking Road, Plaistow, laundryman on July 22 I visited my stables at Portland Road, and found them of correct. The next day the stable had been broken into and the golding, car, harness, and lamps stolen. On August 13 I saw the car at Minorles Police Station.

JOHN ERYCE , 417, Holloway Road. I have stable in Holloway Road. On Sunday, August 11, between three and four, prisoner drove up to my house with my boy. He had my horse in the trap, me boy having lent it him to trot out with the trap. Prisoner santed me to buy the trap for £16. I went for a run with it, and it seemed all right. I eventually agreed to give him £10 and my old trap for it, which I did on the Wednesday evening at six o'clock. Meanwhile on the next two days I went out with the trap, and on the second one I was stopped by a constable, with whom I went to the Minories Police Station, and was detained for six hours till my statement was investigated, on which I was released. On the next day, the 16th, prisoner came about 5.30 to receive the money. As he was signing the receipt Detective Eustace came in and arrested him.

Cross-examined. I had never seen prisoner before the Sunday that he called. Prisoner first called at my stables and borrowed the cob to drive the trap to my house. I am pretty well known in the neighbourhood, and sometimes buy traps in the course of busi
ness. After wanting £16 prisoner came down to £13 before accept
ing £10. My old trap was worth about £5. I told prisoner I had not the money at the time, and he agreed to wait till the Wednes
day. He gave me his name as Henry Jones, 29, Halton Road, Islington. I arranged to pay prisoner in cash. When he had written the receipt, I said, "I will go outside and blot it." Whilst I was going out, prisoner said, "I am glad you are satisfied with the trap, and I will do anything for you in the future." I then handed the receipt to Detective Eustace, who asked who prisoner was. I told him, and he informed prisoner that he was a police officer, and understood that the trap had been stolen, asking him where he got it. Prisoner said he got it from a man outside a public-house in Holloway Road or Caledonian Road on August 9 for £13. The man was a stranger. The market in Caledonian Road to a well known place for buying horses. Prisoner said there had been a horse in the trap and he had taken it out and pulled the trap round to his stables.
Re-examined. Prisoner gave Eustace the address of 24, Halton Road.

Detective-sergeant EUSTACE. K Division. On August 14 I went to 417, Holloway Road, and saw prisoner in the front room with Mr. Bryce. I saw prisoner writing a receipt (produced). After telling him the charge, prisoner said, in answer to questions. "I bought it from a man on the 9th inst. He asked me £16 for it; I gave him £13. I was standing in the Holloway Road when I saw the man with it. He was driving it. He took the horse out of the cart and I pulled it round to my stable, a few yards from the address I have given you. I do not know the man I bought it from; I never saw him before; I haven't seen him since, and I have no idea where he may be seen. I do not know nobody that saw me buy it, and I cannot give you any further information." He gave his name as Henry Jones, 24, Halton Road, Islington. I took him to the sta
tion; subsequently to West Ham. He made no reply when charged I went to the address given; prisoner was not known there, and there was no stable near the house. I asked for White, as well as Jones.
Cross-examined. Halton Road would be about two miles from Caledonian Market. There is no mews in Halton Road. I went to No. 29 as well as 24.

Prisoner's statement at the police court: "All I have got to say is I appeal against the charge of having received the trap. I acknowledge I bought the trap and sold it to the gentleman. The other things I know nothing of."
(Defence.)

HENRY WHITE (prisoner, on oath). I was going up the market—we call it Smithfield—on Friday, August 9; I was standing outside the public-house in Holloway Road, near the railway arch, about quarter to one, when a man drove up in a horse and cart. He says, "Will you buy that lot?" I says, "No." "Buy the cart then." He asked £16; I said, "No, I will give you £10." He finally ac
cepted £13. I said, "I have nowhere to put it; I have no horse; where can I put it?" He said, "There is a mews down here is Halton Road; go and put it down there and leave it." He directed me the way down and I went, took the trap, and left it there. I paid for the trap at the time I bought it. On the Sunday following I went to Mr. Bryce, having been told he wanted to buy a trap. I went to his stables first, asked his chap if it was true Mr. Bryce wanted a trap; he said, "Yes," and told me to take mine up to his guv'nor. He lent me the cob, and I went to Halton Road to fetch the trap, the boy coming with me. We then drove back to the stable, and from thence to Mr. Bryce's house. What passed be
tween us was substantially what he had said; also on the Wednesday when the detective came. I generally sign receipts, "Henry Jones."

Cross-examined. There were hundred of people about when I bought the cart on August 9. I have not brought anyone who saw do it; I am a stranger about there. I had the money with which I bought the trap in gold in my pocket. I think the mews was at 29, Halton Road. I have nobody here from it. When I went to the mews to fetch the trap I left the boy in a public-house near while I fetched it. I live at Deptford. The detective never asked me where I lived; I gave the address where the trap was. I always buy things in the name of Jones. The money I bought the trap with was borrowed from my niece the day previous; I always get money off my niece. I do not live on her. Her husband is a green-grocer. I reckon I gave almost the full value for the trap. I do not ask questions when I buy in the market, and do not get receipts. I asked the boy if he would stop at the public-house while I fetched the trap; he said, "All right." He could have come if he liked.

To the Judge. They buy and sell anything at the Caldonian Market. I have no place to keep a horse or cart when I buy it. I sell a horse as quick as I can. Close to where I live there is a big forest where you can turn a horse out; they charge you nothing. I have turned out hundreds of them there.

Verdict,
Guilty.

In 1873 prisoner received 12 months' hard labour for stealing; in 1874, at the Middlesex Sessions, seven years' penal servitude, stealing a horse; in 1880, eight years' penal servitude and five years' supervision; in 1888, six years' penal servitude; in 1893 seven years; in 1900 seven years.

Sentence,
Five years' penal servitude.

p.rs:
; feloniously marrying
Charles Winter, her husband being then alive; making a false declaration for insertion in the register of marriage of the parish of Stepney;

, aiding, counselling, and procuring
Edith Dickenson to feloniously marry him, her husband being then alive.

div1.p: Dickenson pleaded guilty.

ELIZABETH KATE KNIGHT , 13, Osborn Road, Southampton. I was present at Northam Parish Church on April 27, 1896, when the female prisoner was married to
George Dickenson. I always knew her before that by the name of
Mcivor , but that was not her proper name. She was married in the name of
Twigdon , according to the register. I knew them for about two years after they were married.
Cross-examined. As far as I know they were living together. I did not see them after that for some years. I do not know Winter at all.

ELIZABETH WHITTAKER , 27, Nelson Street, Tidal Basin. I have known Edith Dickenson for four or five years. Twelve months ago she was living at 3, Francis Street, with Charles Winter, and had been while I had known them. I once saw Edith Dickenson and

Winter with the man Dickenson, in the "Freemasons' Tavern," Vic
toria Dock Road; that was a good way back, but during the time she lived with Winter. I knew Dickenson was her husband, be
cause I have seen the marriage lines. He came to the house when Winter was not there. I had a room off Mrs. Dickenson in Francis Street. On the day the case first came on Mrs. Dickenson asked me to go and tell Winter to clear out, as he had no right there when her husband was at home. I never heard Winter mention Mrs. Dickenson's husband to her. I do not remember being asked at the police court if I had; I never knew anything about Winter and Mrs. Dickenson being married.

Cross-examined. Mrs. Dickenson always went by that name. I think she lived rather a loose sort of life, because she had the two men coming backward and forward. Both Winter and Dickenson were seamen. When they were both away she had the two half-pays. At those times I have seen men go in with her, but have not seen them sleep with her. It is 12 months since I left Mrs. Dickenson's place.
JULIA SHED . I was present on May 16, 1907, at Stepney Registry Office, when Edith Dickenson was married to Winter.

Cross-examined. Mrs. Dickenson declared to the registrar that she was a spinster; I always thought she was. I have heard about a husband named Dickenson. I had known Mrs. Dickenson for about eight months before the marriage. I knew Mr. Dickenson before the marriage, but not as Mrs. Dickenson's husband.

THOMAS GEORGE STACEY , Registry Office, Stepney, proved the mar
riage of the two prisoners, Winter and Dickenson, on May 16, 1907. (Copy register produced.)

SARAH DAVIS . I have known the two prisoners for four or five years as man and wife. I lived next door to them 2 1/2 years ago at Custom House. During that time I have seen the man Dickenson at the house. One day Mrs. Dickenson came to me and asked if I would let Charlie (Winter) stop with me as her husband was home. When Winter was in my house he said to me, "She has no business with her old man as her husband, as he knocks her about so." When Dickenson left Winter returned to Mrs. Dickenson. This happened during the six months before I left. Winter knew that Dickenson was married to the female prisoner.

Cross-examined. It was in my kitchen one Sunday evening that Winter spoke about Mrs. Dickenson's husband; there was another young man present. I turned round and said to Winter, "Oh, shut up, don't make any noise; I don't want murder in my house." He was rather upset about Dickenson being next door with his wife. I know Mrs. Dickenson used to get half-pay from her husband as well as from Winter, and the letter knew it too. I knew nothing bout the marriages.

Detective-sergeant
GEORGE READ deposed to going to see Mrs. Dickenson on August 22.
(Evidence not admitted.)

Detective
JOSEPH PAIN , K Division, deposed to arresting Winter, and telling him the charge, when he said, "All right." At the Sta
tion he said, "That's what she told me."
Winter statement before the magistrate: "I plead not guilty and reserve my defence."

Verdict,
Guilty.
Both prisoners were released on their own re
cognisances in £10 to come up for judgement if called upon.
(Thursday, September 19.)

BUTLER, Samuel (47 labourer),
pleaded guilty
to indecently assaulting
Ethel Sweetland and assaulting her. Sentence,
Two months' heard labour.
BEFORE THE RECORDER.
>(Friday, September 20.)

p.rs:
, attempting to carnally know
Maud Alice Cook, a girl above the age of 13 years and under the age of 16 years.

div1.p: Mr. Eustance Fulton prosecuted.

Verdict,
Guilty. Sentence,
Nine months' hard labour.
BEFORE THE RECORDER.
(Tuesday, September 10.)

div0.p:
WATSON, Sophia Annie, was found guilty last session (see page 621) of failing to notify to the police change of residence whilst a convict. (Prevention of Crimes Act.) It was now stated that, on the expiry of any sentence passed for this offence, prisoner would in ordinary course be sent back to the convict prison to complete or to serve such further part of her original term as the Home Secre
tary might direct. In these circumstances the Recorder passed a sentence of two days imprisonment.

div1.p:
JOHNSON, Charles (22, engineer). and
OWEN, James (21, labourer),
pleaded guilty to
burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Cockburn and stealing therein 179 gold rings and other articles, his property.
Mr. Ricardo prosecuted.

Sentence, each prisoner,
Two years' hard labour.
Mr. Ricardo asked his lordship if he would mention the conduct of the police.

Judge Lumley Smith objected that there were so many cases now in which an expression as to the conduct of the police was asked for. It was becoming a regular business, and he thought was a little over
done. The police were expected to do their duty, and of course in this case they were quite right. But he did not know that any extraordinary ability was required to stop two men at night carrying a bag on Richmond Green. He should think that was about what any policeman would do. He had been asked before that day to pass a commendation on the police, and it was becoming a little too common; but he always liked to encourage the police, and they had done very well on this occasion.
